results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Murder Under the Mistletoe (Series 02. Ep. 13)
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Fiona Eagger, Deb Cox, Screen Australia and Every Cloud Productions
results.brief_description: Phryne, Dot and Dr Mac happily accompany Aunt Prudence to a picturesque chalet to celebrate a white Christmas in July. The party arrives to find one of the residents dead – electrocuted while hanging festive lights. No more suspicious than the usual Miss Fisher investigation, until the body count starts to rapidly rise. Heavy snowfalls and harsh weather trap them all with a murderer in their midst – and any one of them the next victim. It’s a race against time for Phryne and Jack to hunt down the culprit – and restore enough Christmas joy to take full advantage should they find themselves standing under that bunch of that mistletoe! [Source: Every Cloud Productions]

results.title: Ivan the Terrible = Ivan der Schreckliche [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Motoko Sakaguchi, Videoland and Naxos Deutschland
results.brief_description: Performance of Sergei Prokofiev’s “Ivan the Terrible” in two acts by the Ballet and Orchestra of the Bolshoi Opera Moscow at the Bolshoi Theater. Choreography by Yuri Grigorovich and featuring dancers Yuri Vladimirov, Batalya Bessmertnaya, Boris Akimov and Anastasya Akimov. Note: subtext is in Russian and credits in German.

results.title: Ivan Groznyi = Ivan the Terrible. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Sergei Eisenstein, Alma-Ata Studios and Central Cinema Studios
results.brief_description:
The first two parts of Eisenstein’s intended trilogy on on the unification of Russia under the 16th century Czar. In the trilogy Eisenstein planned to show the inner struggle of the first Czar of Russia and founder of the Russian state, in his effort to consolidate the unity of the realm against its enemies at home - the boyars or feudal noblemen - and neighbouring powers. Ivan the Terrible part I is Eisenstein’s boldest and most successful experiment in stylisation drawing upon other arts - Wagnerian opera, Marinsky ballet and Japanese Kabuki theatre - which he had begun in ‘Alexander Nevsky’. Ivan’s personal life is interwoven with the themes of his drive for empire and his alliance with the merchant class against the aristocracy. Part II, the last film Eisenstein made, is dominated by cloak-and-dagger intrigue. It was completed in 1946 but not released until 1959. It takes up the story of Ivan the Terrible upon his return to Moscow from Alexandrov. The complex story is full of intrigue, high level political in-fighting, family resentment and suspicion, and assassination plot, executions and murder in the cathedral. Two reels of the original were filmed in colour. The banquet scene towards the end of the film was Eisenstein’s first use of colour stock. Part 3 which was to be in colour, was designed but never filmed. Pts. I and II also available separately on VHS. Pt. I also available separately on 16mm.

Credits: Director, writer, Sergei Eisenstein ; photography, Andrei Moskvin, Edouard Tisse ; music, Sergei Prokofiev.
Cast: Nikolai Cherkassov, Ludmila Tselikovskaya, Serafima Birman, Ludmila Tselikovskaya.

results.title: Ivan and Abraham = Moi Ivan, toi Abraham [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Yolande Zauberman, Jean-Luc Ormieres, Rene Cleitman, Films Balenciaga, UGC Images and Hatchette Premiere
results.brief_description: This beautifully directed and photographed debut feature film by Franco-Polish filmmaker, Yoldande Zauberman, is set in a 1930s Polish shtetl, or small Jewish community, during a time of impending religious and political tensions leading up to Hitler’s invasion of Poland. It tells of a unique and special friendship between two young boys, Abraham (Roma Alexandrovitch), a nine year-old Jewish boy and Ivan (Sacha Iakovlev), a fourteen year-old Catholic boy, and their determination to remain best friends as religious prejudices begin to surface in the Polish community and within Abraham’s own family. When Abraham’s grandfather tries to stop the boys from seeing one another, they decide to runaway together. Added to this family drama is the alienation between Abraham’s teenage sister, Rachel (Marina Lipkina) and their father, who disapproves of Rachel’s relationship with Aaron (Vladimir Machkov), a young Communist activist. Aaron and Rachel also take flight to escape the prejudices and intolerances and to seek out Abraham and Ivan. The film focuses on these four young outcasts, their relationships and the drama of living in uncertain times. Filmed evocatively in black and white with quite an impressive young cast, “Ivan and Abraham” captures the essence of life between the Wars in Eastern Europe and the intolerances which existed, not only religiously, but politically and ethnically. Cast also includes Alexandre Kaliaguine, Helene Lapiower, Rolan Bykov, Zinovi Guerdt. In Yiddish, Polish, Russian and Gypsy dialect with English subtitles. (Awards: Cannes, 1993; Moscow, 1993)
results.title_for_label: Ivan and Abraham = Moi Ivan, toi Abraham [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Yolande Zauberman, Jean-Luc Ormieres, Rene Cleitman, Films Balenciaga, UGC Images and Hatchette Premiere

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Cocaine Blues (Series 01. Ep. 01)
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Fiona Eagger, Deb Cox, Screen Australia and Every Cloud Productions
results.brief_description: The Honourable Miss Phryne Fisher disembarks the Orient at Victoria Dock, returning to Melbourne after years abroad. Almost as soon as she checks into the Windsor Hotel, Phryne is embroiled in mystery: poisoned husbands, cocaine smuggling rings and illegal abortionists – not to mention erotic encounters with the handsome Russian dancer, Sasha de Lisse. Her adventure reaches its steamy end in the Turkish Bath Palace off Little Lonsdale Street. [Source: Every Cloud Productions]

results.title: Itzhak Perlman: Beethoven violin concerto in D, op. 61
results.brief_description: This video recording of Beethoven’s violin concerto in D, op. 61 was produced in the studio and features the exquisite music of Israeli born violin virtuoso, Itzhak Perlman accompanied by the Philharmonia Orchestra (leader, Carl Pini) and world-renowned conductor, Carlo Maria Giulini.

results.title: Italy: where the past is always present
results.brief_description: Gives historical overview and examines the Italian influence on civilisation through the ages, from the rise and fall of the Roman Empire, through the Renaissance to postwar industrialisation. Looks at present day Italy and the Italian love of life and considers social and political problems such as the gap between north and south.

results.title: On the run
results.creator_credit: Pat Jackson, Derek Williams and C F F Productions
results.brief_description: A girl runs away from a welfare worker and encounters two boys. One of the boys is the son of an ousted African leader. When the girl overhears a plot by the leader’s treacherous brother to kidnap the leader’s son, she rescues him with the aid of the other boy and the trio go on the run pursued by the leader’s brother and his henchman. Stars Gordon Jackson, Denis Conoley, Robert Kennedy and Tracy Collins. Based on the book by Nina Bawden; script by Pat Jackson; camera by Stephen Dade; music by William Davies.

results.title: Italy
results.brief_description: Informative film which visits the cities and towns of Italy. A geographical overview is given and aspects of Italian life are looked at, such as the importance of religion and cultural differences between north and south. Visits Milan, Naples, Rome and the Vatican. Historical reviews of places are given, including Pompeii. Looks at wine, olive, fruit and pasta production and the contributions that Italy makes to design, furniture, clothes and the car industry.
